title: Implement cleanup strategy display with color coding
description:
Add visual phase between discovery and confirmation:

**Phase: Strategy Preview** - Show cleanup plan for each project with color coding.

**Colors:**
- GREEN: Safe commands (cargo clean, npm ci, gradle clean) - will be executed
- YELLOW: Tentative commands (make clean) - exists in Makefile but uncertain
- RED: Paths/globs to be deleted (target/, node_modules/, *.o) - destructive

**Format:**


**Implementation:**
1. Create CleanupStrategy struct with:
   - safeCommands: [(command: String, color: .green)]
   - tentativeCommands: [(command: String, color: .yellow)]
   - pathsToDelete: [(path: String, glob: String?, size: UInt64)]
2. For each project type in CLEANUP_RECIPES.md, populate strategy
3. Display in preview phase with colors
4. Calculate total space freed across all projects
5. User sees exact plan before confirmation

Depends on: devdug-2fu (cleanup strategy definitions) ✓ complete
Blocked by: None

title: Post-mortem: Lost Android Studio projects to careless cleanup
description:
Lesson learned: User accidentally deleted all Android Studio projects yesterday while trying to free disk space using ad-hoc rm commands.

**Why this can't happen with devdug:**

1. **Strategy Preview mandatory** - Must see exactly what will be deleted before confirmation
2. **Multiple confirmations** - Can't proceed without explicit double confirmation
3. **Color-coded warnings** - RED paths stand out as destructive actions
4. **Cleanup status bar** - User always knows what phase they're in (Discovery → Display → Strategy → Confirm → Execute)
5. **Logging** - Future: log all deletions to ~/devdug-cleanup.log
6. **Non-interactive safety** - Can't accidentally run with wrong flags

**Design implications:**
- Strategy Preview is NOT optional - it's the safety valve
- Top status bar prevents confusion about what's happening
- Execution phase stays blocked until preview+confirmation working perfectly

This project exists to solve this exact problem.

title: Add unit tests for cleanup logic
description: Write comprehensive unit tests for the file cleanup and deletion logic in the core module

title: Define cleanup strategies for each project type
description:
Map project types to cleanup strategies (both approaches):

**Approach 1: Safe command execution** (when available)
- cargo → cargo clean
- npm → npm ci --prefer-offline (reinstall from lock)
- gradle → ./gradlew clean
- maven → mvn clean

**Approach 2: Direct deletion of artifacts** (always works, calculates space)
- cargo → rm -rf target/
- npm → rm -rf node_modules/ (recalculate: npm install from lock)
- python-pip → rm -rf __pycache__/ dist/ build/ *.egg-info/
- gradle → rm -rf build/
- maven → rm -rf target/
- xcode → rm -rf ~/Library/Developer/Xcode/DerivedData/ProjectName-*
- intellij-idea → rm -rf .idea/cache/ .idea/caches/ .idea/shelf/
- eclipse → rm -rf .metadata/ .recommenders/ .settings/ bin/
- cmake → rm -rf cmake-build-*/
- go → rm -rf vendor/ (if vendor dir)

Benefit of paths: pre-calculate total disk space that will be freed and show in --clean mode before user confirms.

Create CleanupStrategy struct with both fields, use command when safe else fall back to paths.
